repnme.cdata!:
Lithuania - Enterprise and Financial Sector
            Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated as highly
            satisfactory and project sustainability is adjudged highly
            likely. The World Bank's lending and supervision
            performance is rated highly satisfactory. The
            Borrower's overall performance is rated satisfactory,
            despite discontinuities in the Government. Notwithstanding
            the overall success of the project, there were both positive
            and negative lessons learned, some on details in design and
            implementation, and some on a more general level: In-built
            flexibility of design to deal with inevitable changes in
            cirsumstances and environment is an important feature. For
            example, the alignment of the interest spreads to market
            rates should not only be made possible but be made more or
            less automatic in this type of product. This would have
            speeded up the implementation of such changes and thus
            speeded up disbursements in regard to this project.
            Flexibility by the Bank in admitting mistakes in the design
            and excessive bureaucracy in regard to implementation are
            also essential. Without comprehensively focused and
            well-organized technical assistance for all components as
            well as needed improvements in the legal anf regulatory
            framework, the project would not have succeeded as well as
            it did or might even have failed to reach its objectives.
            Generally, the timing of an investment operation to assist
            the enterprise and financial sectors is key. When
            governments frequently change, the Bank needs to ensure that
            reforms are realized up front.

repnme.cdata!:
Lithuania - Enterprise and Financial Sector
            Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Enterprise &
            Financial Sector Assistance Project is to support the
            Government's reform efforts in the enterprise and
            financial sectors, focusing in particular on strengthening
            the banking system and on the delivery of finance to support
            the development of private and privatized enterprises. The
            project comprises a credit line and a technical assistance
            component. The credit line component will provide resources
            through qualified participating banks for medium-term loans
            to private enterprises. The technical assistance component
            will aim at overcoming deficiencies in: 1) bank regulation
            and supervision; 2) commercial banks' institutional
            capacity and appraisal skills; 3) the Government's
            capacity to reorganize/liquidate inviable state-owned
            enterprises; and 4) enterprise strategic planning
            capability. In addition, targeted assistance will be
            provided to ensure that sub-projects are adequately screened
            for environmental impact.

docna.cdata!:
Lithuania - Enterprise and Financial Sector
            Assistance Project

display_title.display_title:
Lithuania - Enterprise and
            Financial Sector Assistance Project
